II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Six large islands, dozens of smaller islands, and hundreds of islets and atolls make up 
the 28,000 square kilometers in land area of Solomon Islands. More than 80% of the population 
is rural, living in widely dispersed villages of a few hundred persons. Infrastructure and services, 
especially in the rural areas, are inadequate. Improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness 
of  the  national  road  network  under  the  project  will  make  the  rural  areas  more  accessible  and 
promote development. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
The  economy  is  based  on  primary  commodities  from  agriculture,  forestry,  and  fishing. 
3. 
Jobs are limited: only about a quarter of the population is formally employed. Income-generating 
opportunities in the rural areas are scarce. Infrastructure investments are needed for economic 
growth, employment, poverty reduction, and social development. 
 
4. 
The  road  network  reaches  only  about  a  quarter  of  the  rural  villages.  About  60%  of  the 
network  is  on  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  which  serve  about  90%  of  the  traffic  in  the  country. 
Sealed  or  graveled  roads  are  confined  to  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  which  also  have  the  only 
significant inland roads, and a segment of secondary road in the Western Province. The other 
six provinces have relatively short coastal segments of gravel or earth roads near the provincial 
centers. Widespread deferment of maintenance has left provincial and secondary roads in the 
rural provinces so badly deteriorated that they can no longer be maintained and urgently need 
rehabilitation.  At  the  Government’s  request,  the  Solomon  Islands  Road  Improvement  (Sector) 
Project  (SIRIP)  was  prepared  and  is  now  being  implemented  with  a  preferential  focus  on 
addressing  the  urgent  need  in  the  underserved  parts  of  the  country.  2  A  chronology  of  events 
under SIRIP is in Appendix 2 and an analysis of the road subsector is in Appendix 3.   
 
5. 
The proposed project will implement the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) strategy for 
Solomon  Islands  by  (i) upgrading  and  preserving  transport  infrastructure,  (ii) facilitating  the 
expansion  of  transport  services,  (iii) strengthening  the  enabling  environment  for  private  sector 
development,  and  (iv) providing  opportunities  for  the  private  sector  and  local  communities  to 
participate  directly  in  the  project  activities.  Further,  the  project  will  guide  future  external 
assistance  in  the  road  subsector  through  better  aid  coordination  and  consistent  development 
planning, while serving as a basis for the Government’s investments in the subsector.

1. 

The Government’s Sector Strategy 

6. 
The  Government’s  development  vision,  priorities,  and  strategies  are  expressed  in  the 
Medium-Term  Development  Strategy  (MTDS)  2008–2010. 3   There  are  six  priorities:  (i) 
reconciliation  and  rehabilitation,  (ii)  national  security  and  foreign  relations,  (iii)  infrastructure 
development, (iv) social services, (v) the economic and productive sectors, and (vi) civic affairs. 
Infrastructure  development  and  private  sector–led  growth  also  have  high  priority.  The 
Government  has  announced  its  intention  to  align  budget  formulation  and  implementation  with 
these  priorities,  especially  in  the  delivery  of  essential  services  and  policy  reform.  The 
second-largest  slice  of  program  funds  under  MTDS  2008–2010,  after  the  economic  and 
productive sectors, goes to infrastructure programs. The transport policies in MTDS 2008–2010 
emphasize  the  need  to  rehabilitate  and  maintain  infrastructure  to  reverse  past  neglect  and 
provide better market access and service delivery, for rural development.  
 
7. 
With ADB assistance, the Government has prepared its National Transport Plan (NTP) 
and  created  the  transport  policy  and  planning  unit  (TPPU)  under  the  Ministry  of  Infrastructure 
Development  (MID).4  The  NTP  provides  the  strategic  framework  and  a  3-year  action  plan  for 
developing and maintaining physical infrastructure, facilitating transport services, improving the 
capacity  of government  agencies, and  increasing  private  sector  participation.  It  is centered  on 
(i) rehabilitating high-priority roads and bridges on Guadalcanal and Malaita; (ii) extending such 
rehabilitation  to  other  provinces;  (iii) strengthening  the  capacity  to  manage  projects,  contracts, 
and road assets; and (iv) promoting the participation of the private sector, communities, women, 
and youth groups in road maintenance. 
 
To  implement  the  NTP,  Parliament  passed  the  National  Transport  Fund  (NTF)  Act 
8. 
creating the NTF in 2008. Government funds for transport infrastructure improvement are now 
channeled through the NTF and managed by TPPU, but regulations for the full operation of the 
NTF  under  a  board  of  directors  are  being  prepared.  The  Government’s  transport  task  force, 
comprising representatives from key government agencies, advises MID and the TPPU on key 
issues, development options, and priorities. The Government has also embarked on institutional 
reforms, with ADB assistance, to reinforce its capacity to implement a sector project effectively. 
The  comprehensive  implementation  assistance  and  capacity  building  under  SIRIP  has  also 
resulted in greater community involvement, sector plans that are more responsive to community 
needs,  and  rural  economic  development  through  increased  productivity  and  opportunities  for 
occasional labor.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  

13. 
As a fragile country emerging from several years of conflict and, more recently, natural 
disasters,  Solomon  Islands  is  confronting  many  challenges  and  opportunities.  The  most 
pressing needs are (i) sustained economic growth, (ii) more employment and income-generating 
opportunities,  (iii)  a  stronger  institutional  framework  for  managing  and  administering  public 
sector  responsibilities,  and  (iv)  improved  human  and  institutional  capacity.  Progress  in  these 
areas is expected to contribute directly to reducing poverty.

challenge. Financial constraints, poor equipment maintenance, and geographic conditions have 
contributed  to  poor  road  maintenance  for  many  years.  As  a  result,  many  roads  need 
rehabilitation  so  that  they  can  be  maintained  once  again  and  support  traffic.  However,  the 
government  budget  provides  only  for  maintenance  and  not  for  new  investments,  and  the  high 
debt burden rules out further borrowing. Therefore, projects must be prioritized and sequenced 
to  maximize  the  benefits.  Past  efforts,  directed  mostly  at  basic  maintenance  and  emergency 
works,  were  inadequate  and  costly.  A  shift  to  sustainable  rehabilitation  and  preventive  asset 
management is needed to keep the network fit for use.  
 
16. 
Road  Network  Development.  Because  of  poor  asset  management,  about  70%  of  the 
road  network  can  no  longer  be  maintained,  and  requires  reconstruction  or  rehabilitation.  The 
Government has invested about $11 million from domestic sources and $96 million in external 
funding  in  the  road  subsector  over  the  past  2  decades  (Appendix  5).  Improvements  on  about 
140 km  of  national  roads  under  ongoing  projects  will  guarantee  all-weather  access. 8   The 
rehabilitation of about 200 km is being carried out under the Community Sector Program of the 
Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID). These interventions have achieved 
all-weather  access on  almost  all  national  roads.  However,  on  provincial and  secondary  roads, 
bridges  must  be  repaired  or  replaced,  pavement  reshaped  and  strengthened,  and  drainage 
improved.  Village  and  farm  roads  also  need  improvement  to  allow  poor  rural  communities  to 
share in the benefits.  
 
17. 
Road  Maintenance  Funds  and  Budgeting.  Roads  are  being  maintained  as  they  are 
gradually being rehabilitated. Road maintenance funding has increased by an average of 20% 
yearly since the start of SIRIP. The maintenance funds have increased but are still not enough. 
Road inventories and condition surveys are being undertaken as part of the NTP update. The 
results  will  feed  into  the  road  asset  management  system,  which  will  generate  annual 
maintenance funds for the network. Maintaining the rehabilitated lengths of road to all-weather 
access conditions will continue to require investment support. 
 
18. 
Lessons.  Historically,  most  projects  in  the  road  subsector  have  used  force-account 
procedures, and only a few have been done under contract. Projects lacked quality at entry and 
were  built  to  poor  standards,  and  were  therefore  unsustainable.  Key  institutional  and  policy 
issues  were  not  resolved;  these  included  (i) inaction  on  the  overloading  of  logging  trucks, 
(ii) shortfall  in  maintenance  funding  in  favor  of  capital  expenditure,  (iii) failure  to  institutionalize 
an  effective  asset  management  system,  and  (iv) limited  national  contracting  capacity  for  road 
maintenance  and  rehabilitation.  SIRIP  has  made  significant  advances  in  (i) addressing  the 
funding  issue  through  the  legal  establishment  of  the  NTF,  (ii) setting  up  asset  management 
systems within MID, and (iii) encouraging the formation of small and medium-sized enterprises 
to  undertake  road  maintenance  with  LBES  techniques  under  simple  contract  procedures.  The 
new  LBES  techniques  have  proven  successful  but  require  close  attention  to  training, 
supervision,  and  performance  standards,  as  well  as commitment  to  routine  maintenance  once 
the roads have been rehabilitated.

23. 
Pro-poor  economic  growth  and  improvement  in  social  and  health  indicators  call  for  a 
revitalized and decentralized rural economy. Poor roads constrain the movement of people and 
goods  and  discourage  productive  rural  activity.  Transport  infrastructure  and  services  must 
improve to provide reliable access to domestic and international markets for rural produce and 
commodities,  and  thereby  (i)  restart  and  build  rural  economies,  (ii)  reduce  the  migration  of 
people  in  search  of  employment,  (iii)  decrease  conflict  between  groups  competing  for  limited 
opportunities,  and  (iv)  restore  basic  social  services  in  rural  areas.  Improved  rural  accessibility 
will help reduce poverty.

1. 

Project Economic Justification 

Two sample subprojects have been assessed. The estimated EIRR of the Guadalcanal 
55. 
subproject is 42%, reflecting the central importance of restoring this main transport route to the 
national economy.  The financial costs and economic evaluation of the Makira subproject, based

country,  and  its  need  for  economic  stimulus  and  investment. 17  Considering  that  some  input 
parameters have been estimated conservatively and that a number of project benefits have not 
been quantified, sensitivity analysis shows the subproject to be reasonably robust to variations 
in input. The most sensitive variable is the construction cost, but the receipt of tenders before 
project  approval  will  allow  this  risk  to  be  closely  managed.  The  EIRR  is  detailed  in 
Supplementary Appendix E.

Technical Risks 

The  design  of  bridges  at  the  larger  river  crossings  mitigates  against  the  risk  of  flood 
71.

reinstatement,  disruption  consequences,  and  construction  cost.  Other  structures  are  designed

observation and surveys; drilling to establish foundation conditions for bridge structures will be 
undertaken at the start of implementation. There is some technical risk that adverse foundation 
conditions could require deeper piling than estimated or reconsideration of the design solution 
or increased cost. The road alongside the flood plains will be raised and sealed with bitumen to 
prevent  the  erosion  of  pavement  materials  during  floods.  The  sections  of  road  lengths 
encountering a high water table will be raised with improved drainage. This risk is mitigated by 
an allowance for risk contingencies within the base cost estimate.

4. 

Post-Conflict Environment  

77.  While  the  post-conflict  environment  is  stable,  the  economy  has  not  recovered 
substantially  and  is  adversely  affected  by  the  current  global  economic  financial  crisis.  The

respond  to  business  opportunities.  If  political  instability  increases  or  there  is  a  deterioration  in 
law and order, reduced interest in the project among prospective bidders could increase tender 
prices  and  lessen  community  support  for  the  project.  Continuing  large-scale,  long-term 
assistance from development partners in the economic and post-conflict recovery efforts of the 
Government will mitigate this risk. 
 

5. 

Financial Risks 

78. 
Government  counterpart  contributions,  particularly  where  cash  payments  are  required 
for rehabilitation, road maintenance, and counterpart staff could be inadequate because of the 
ongoing  impact  of  the  global  economic  and  financial  crisis,  despite  assurances.  The  risks 
related  to  government  counterpart  financing  will  be  mitigated  by:  (i) the  relatively  small 
proportion of government financing (4.83%) limits the effects on project objectives of any delay 
or  reduction  in  the  contribution;  (ii)  the  ADB-supported  full  operation  of  the  NTF  provides  a 
secure  channel  of  financing  for  road  maintenance;  and  (iii)  the  inclusion  of  taxes  on  fuel  and 
plant inputs (but not gross sales tax) in project cost allows shortfalls in the Government’s cash 
contribution to be covered by a tax credit against tax components of the construction cost. The 
counterpart contributions are relatively small in amount, and are within MID’s ability to manage 
through the annual budget cycle. 
 
79. 
The state of the construction market, the relative remoteness of the subprojects, and the 
volatility of exchange rates and unit costs of construction input create a financial risk up to the 
point of receipt and acceptance of construction tenders. This risk can be partially mitigated by 
calling  for  tenders  in  advance  of  project  approval,  providing  an  opportunity  to  adjust  the 
subproject  scope  and  design  if  necessary.  The  early  tendering  of  all  the  rehabilitation 
components will also mitigate the risks of inflationary effects over the term of the project.  
 
Adequate  financial  management  skills  within  MID,  supported  by  the  PMU,  will  be 
80. 
important for the achievement of the project’s objectives and the long-term sustainability of its 
impact. A financial management assessment found a significant improvement in procedures and

6. 

Environmental Impact Risks 

81. 
Subproject  approval  processes  are  part  of  the  environmental  assessment  and  review 
procedure set out in Supplementary Appendix A. The initial environmental examination (IEE) for 
the  Makira  core  subproject  (Supplementary  Appendix B)  posted  on  ADB’s  website  has  been 
accepted. Another IEE, for the Guadalcanal subproject (Supplementary Appendix C), concluded 
that the environmental impact will be minimal and can be readily mitigated.  The  Guadalcanal 
subproject  is  in  a  coastal  area  where  coconut  and  cocoa  plantations  are  interspersed  with 
subsistence gardens and regenerating scrubland. There are no protected areas or community-
based marine protected areas in the subproject area. The Guadalcanal subproject will involve 
the  repair  and  rehabilitation  of  culverts,  scour  protection,  river  training  works,  and  the 
reconstruction  or  repair  of  bridges,  all  within  existing  rights-of-way,  and  no  land  acquisition  or 
resettlement will be required.  
 

7. 

Institutional Risks 

82. 
The sustainability of the Project hinges on the availability of dedicated funding for road 
maintenance  and  investment,  supplied  through  the  NTF.  The  NTF  Act  was  passed  by 
Parliament  in  2008  and  operational  regulations  are  now  being  finalized.  In  the  interim,  MID 
provides maintenance funding through a dedicated budget line item. 
 
Continued  progress  in  restructuring  MID  and  developing  its  management  systems  to 
83. 
transform the ministry into a planning and asset management agency depends on the continued 
success  of  reforms  under  ADB  TA  and  adequate  government  funding.  One  risk  is  that  the 
Government’s  commitment  to  reform,  and  the  associated  development  and  implementation  of 
operating and management procedures, could wane. Resource shortages within MID present a 
further risk. The project will mitigate these risks through close collaboration and cooperation with 
the  ongoing  TA,  involving  consultations  between  the  Government,  the  private  sector,  and  the 
general public (footnote 7). ADB project and TA review missions, as well as country consultation 
missions,  will  engage  in  regular  dialogue  with  stakeholders  to  maintain  support  and 
commitment.  
 
84. 
ADB will continue to work closely with development partners to promote improvements 
in  sector  governance,  including  an  operational  NTF  providing  sustainable  funding  for 
infrastructure  maintenance,  program  and  contract  management  capability  within  MID,  and 
private sector contracting capacity, with support from the PMU.  
 

8. 

Climate Change Risks 

85. 
Climate change effects in the South Pacific include a probable increase in the frequency 
and  severity  of  tropical storms  and in  the  associated  rainfall  intensity,  duration,  and  flood  risk. 
Logging in stream catchments reduces the concentration time and increases debris loads. The 
project  will  mitigate  climate  change  risks  to  the  rehabilitation  subprojects  by  funding 
climate change–resistant  designs  for  watercourse  crossings,  reducing  the  risk  that  large  flood 
events  will  destroy  critical  infrastructure,  severing  road  links  with  uncertain  priority,  and  timing 
restoration  projects.  Climate  change  adaptation  measures  are  detailed  in  Supplementary 
Appendix D.

Overall Assessment 

86. 
The  core  road  rehabilitation  subprojects  are  subject  to  technical  risks  that  are  largely 
within the control of MID through the PMU. These risks can be satisfactorily mitigated through 
sound  project  management  and  supervision.  The  design  provides  for  the  mitigation  of  climate 
change  risk.  The  financial  risks  in  regard  to  securing  parallel  financing  and  the  Government’s 
counterpart contribution can be mitigated. The financial risks involved in any variance between 
the  tendered  contract  prices  and  the  design  estimate  will  be  known  by  the  time  the  project  is 
approved. The environmental risks are minor and capable of mitigation. The social effects—the 
benefits  of  new  and  restored  access—are  largely  positive.  Strict  measures  to  control  the 
adverse impact of construction on local communities including HIV control are, or will be, put in

are expected to greatly outweigh the costs, given the recognized risks and mitigation strategy. 
Overall,  the  risks  are  sufficiently  manageable  and  do  not  constitute  any  barriers  to  project 
approval.

A. 

Road Network 

Solomon  Islands  has  a  road  network  of  about  1,950  kilometers  (km)  spread  over 
1. 
30 islands. The network comprises 220 km of main roads, 480 km of secondary roads, 850 km 
of provincial roads, 150 km of Honiara town roads, and about 250 km of private and plantation 
access  roads.  The country  has  an  estimated  800  km  of  logging  roads. The  road  network  also 
has about 200 bridges and is linked by 120 wharves. Sea is the dominant mode of transport in 
Solomon  Islands.  The  Ministry  of  Infrastructure  and  Development  (MID)  manages  all  roads 
comprising main, secondary, provincial, and urban roads. 
 
About  60%  of  the  network  (excluding  Honiara  town  roads)  is  on  Guadalcanal  and 
2. 
Malaita,  which  serve  about  90%  of  the  traffic  in  the  country.  About  1,570  km  have  a  graveled 
surface  and  about  100  km  of  main  roads,  mostly  on  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  and  50  km  of 
Honiara  town  roads  are  sealed.  Other  provinces  have  relatively  short  coastal  segments  of 
gravel  or  earth  roads  around  provincial  centers.  Compared  with  other  Pacific  island  countries, 
the  road  density  is low:  Solomon  Islands  has  less  than  0.07  km  of  road  per  square  kilometer, 
and only 0.005 km per capita. About 23% of villages are accessible by road (normally by cars or 
trucks), 32% by sea, 40% by walking tracks, and 5% by river. 
 
3. 
The  main  roads  serve  the  densely  populated  areas  linking  the  main  centers  with 
commercial centers, markets, and main ports. The secondary roads are extensions to the main 
road network, or serve provincial and subprovincial centers and rural communities on the main 
islands.  Provincial  roads  serve  a  similar  function  to  secondary  roads.  They  also  connect 
agricultural  areas  and  villages  to  wharves,  and  provide  access  to  social  services,  including 
schools, clinics, and markets. 
 
4. 
Apart from the donor-funded road programs, the main, secondary, and provincial roads 
were not built to appropriate standards and have suffered from lack of maintenance over many 
years.1  Routine  maintenance  contracts  currently  exist  over  170  km  of  roads  on  Guadalcanal, 
Temotu, and Malaita under Solomon Islands Road Improvement (Sector) Project (SIRIP), with 
300  km  of  roads  on  Malaita  being  maintained  under  force-account  arrangements  through  the 
Community  Sector  Program  of  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID). 
As  a  result,  the  rest  of  the  network  is  in  poor  condition.  It  provides  inadequate  rural  access, 
thereby  constraining  economic  growth  and  development,  poverty  reduction,  and  social 
development.  In  the  rural  areas,  the  potential  for  cash  crop  production  is  underdeveloped 
primarily because of irregular farm-to-market access, which leaves much of the rural population 
reliant on subsistence livelihoods. Resource-based industries also rely on a suitable standard of 
roads to market their production for export. 
 
5. 
About  65%  of  roads  (those  not  being  maintained)  have  deteriorated  to  such  an  extent 
that  damage  to  vehicles  that  regularly  use  the  roads  is  common,  and  the  roads  are  at  times 
impassable  for  cars  and  light  trucks.  Road  surfaces  are  deformed  and  eroded  in  places, 
drainage  is  not  working  properly,  and  vegetation  is  overgrown,  raising  safety  concerns.  Many

7. 
Solomon Islands has about 11,000 vehicles, 90% of which are on Guadalcanal (75% in 
the  capital Honiara),  8%  in  Malaita,  1%  in  Western,  and the  remaining  1%  in  other  provinces. 
Private cars and taxis, light trucks, and medium trucks (up to 8 tons, 2 axles) are the dominant 
vehicle  types.  Larger  multi-axle  and  articulated  trucks  are  rare  except  in  Honiara  and  specific 
mining  and  logging  areas.  The  fleet  of  large  trucks  in  Guadalcanal  is  forecast  to  increase 
considerably over 2010–2015 with the development of mining and oil palm activities. This might 
result  in  axle  loads  of  up  to  11  tons  (dual-wheel)  and  up  to  8  tons  on  single-wheel  axles. 
Motorcycles, motor scooters, and bicycles are not common in Solomon Islands. 
 
8. 
The  primary  causes  of  road  deterioration  in  Solomon  Islands  are  high  rainfall,  poor 
drainage,  and  lack  of  maintenance,  combined  with  poor  road  construction.  Maintenance  of 
drains  is  essential  in  areas  of  high  rainfall  and  in  steep  areas.  Heavy  axle  loads,  the  primary 
cause of road damage in other countries, are not common in Solomon Islands, except on a few 
mining  and  logging  roads.  However,  with  the  increase  in  heavy  vehicles  in  some  areas,  the 
amount of damage is likely to increase unless roads are properly engineered and constructed 
for  the  higher  loads,  and  laws  against  the  overloading  of  vehicles  are  enforced.  However,  the 
existing  Solomon  Islands  Roads  Act,  1955  is  outdated  and  does  not  adequately  address  the 
overloading of vehicles. Additionally, MID does not have a law enforcement unit and has no staff 
or budget to monitor vehicle loads and law enforcement. 

C. 

Transport Services 

The  majority  of  vehicles  in  the  Solomon  Islands  are  privately  owned.  Privately  owned 
9. 
minibuses  and  taxis  are  the  leading  form  of  public  road  transport,  particularly  in  Honiara. 
Available  public  transport  is  reduced  outside  Honiara.  Public  transport  in  rural  areas  generally 
takes the form of light trucks that combine goods and passenger services. Walking is the most 
common  form  of  travel  for  distances  up  to  10  km.  A  few  small  and  medium-sized  private 
operators provide all the road freight services. In Honiara, a few companies operate heavy and 
articulated  trucks,  and  have  container  transport  capabilities.  In  addition,  private  logging  trucks 
provide services to the forestry sector. Although fares are not regulated, market forces ensure 
they reflect operating costs.

Lessons from SIRIP 

SIRIP  has  introduced  LBES  techniques  for  small-scale  maintenance  contracts  as  a 
13. 
means  of  developing  national  small  and  medium-scale  contractor  capacity.  The  decision  to 
bypass the pilot phase proved successful in speeding up implementation. The proposed project 
will  have  an  opportunity  to  build  on  this  success  by  extending  the  LBES  base  maintenance 
program. Because of their success, LBES techniques are being implemented in other externally 
assisted programs and MID’s own recurrent maintenance programs. 

14. 
The  rehabilitation  component  has  made  slow  progress.  The  need  to  substantially 
modify the  approach from limited rehabilitation of road surfaces to more substantial upgrading 
focused more on waterway crossings was a result of assumptions about the appropriate level of 
intervention in the initial design of SIRIP, based on limited field data and analysis, which turned 
out to be inappropriate. This reorientation also required individual and joint agreements between 
the cofinancing partners and the Government, which have taken some time to achieve. A lesson 
for future projects is the need to acknowledge the risks of designing infrastructure interventions 
with limited field data, and of relying on untested development assumptions. To obtain congruity 
in  development  partner  financing  for  such  sector  projects,  multi-criteria  evaluation  processes 
and  investment  priorities  need  to  be  progressively  agreed  on  among  stakeholders  and 
continuously updated, to achieve the goals of aid coordination set out in the Paris Declaration.3

F. 

Rationale for a Second Phase 

15. 
The second-phase project is proposed (i) to expand the scope of rehabilitation beyond 
Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  (ii)  to  make  permanent  repairs  in  water  crossings  on  Guadalcanal 
West  Road  damaged  by  the  50-year  flood  of  February  2009,  and  (iii)  to  provide  for  climate 
change adaptation. The proposal is consistent with the original objectives of SIRIP and supports 
the Government’s desire for ADB to take the lead in the road subsector and establish a process 
to ensure that aid to the sector is coordinated and more predictable. 

16. 
Without the second phase, the funding shortfall would mean that the Makira subproject 
would have to be reduced in scope, through a reduction in road length and number of waterway 
crossings  rehabilitated  or  upgraded  or  in  the  design  standard  of  the  waterway  crossings,  and 
through  the  exclusion  of  climate  change  adaptation  from  the  design.  In  either  case,  the 
subproject  would  not  fully  achieve  its  objective  of  providing  reliable  and  continuous  access  to 
areas with development potential, to give the population better access to social services, and to 
improve  transport  safety.  Shortening  the  length  of  road  to  be  rehabilitated  or  upgraded  would 
remove  the  highest-return  third  section,  significantly  reducing  the  economic  internal  rate  of 
return.  A  compromise  in  design  standards  would  risk  damage  to  the  investment  from  severe 
flood events, and any new livelihood developed as a result of the road improvement would be 
unsustainable. 

17. 
A  second  phase  will  also  allow  the  continuing  maintenance  of  the  recent  road 
investments made under ADB and  AusAID financing,  before the takeover of this responsibility 
by  the  NTF.  Without  a  second  phase,  a  deferred  maintenance  backlog  would  build  up,  the 
condition  of  the  roads  would  worsen,  and  it  would  be  more  costly  to  return  the  roads  to  their 
current condition.

1. Key Issues  
Project.  According  to  analysis  of  the  Household  Income  and  Expenditure  Survey  2005/06  (HIES)  data  undertaken  by  the 
United Nations Development  Programme, poverty  in the Solomon Islands context does  not mean hunger or  destitution, but 
rather  the  struggle  to  meet  daily  or  weekly  living  expenses,  particularly  those  that  require  cash  payments.  The  definition 
further  included  (i)  households  constantly  having  to  make  choices  between  competing  demands  for  household  expenditure 
and the limited availability of cash income to meet that expenditure; (ii) households having to make trade-offs between one bill 
and another, food or school fees, utilities or bus fares; (iii) households borrowing regularly from loan sharks, who charge very 
high  interest  rates,  for  small  unsecured  loans  to  meet  family  commitments  and  community  obligations;  and  (iv)  households 
that are frequently or constantly in debt. Households deemed to be experiencing basic needs poverty therefore face hardship 
daily.  They  struggle  to  pay  bills  and  purchase  adequate  and  suitably  nutritious  food.  According to  the  estimation  of  poverty 
lines, the HIES showed that the average national incidence of basic needs poverty was 18.8% of households and 22.7% of

meat, cabin biscuits, tinned or powdered milk, noodles, flour; (ii) contribute to school fees or make cash donations to church 
and  ceremonial  activities;  (iii)  improve  the  quality  of  their  houses  (with  corrugated-iron  roofs  and  rainwater  catchments  for

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Makira subproject. About 45% of the population in the vicinity of the subproject road west of Kirarkira town is cut off from the 
provincial  center  during  frequent  flooding  by  the  Waita’a  river.  Water  damage  to  vehicles  deters  the  private  sector  from 
providing  regular  passenger  and  goods  transportation  services  on  the  road  and  passengers  and  cargo  carriers  rely  on 
irregular  and  expensive  sea  transport,  hiring  or  paying  fares  to  travel  on  small  outboard  motor-powered  craft.  Their  limited 
access to Kirakira town, where secondary schools, hospital, shops, market, wharf, airfield, and commodity buyers are located, 
places them at a disadvantage. People reported that life is hard because they cannot make enough  money to meet school 
fees, or improve the quality of their houses (with corrugated-iron roofs and rainwater catchments, for example). Among other 
hardships  people  reportedly  face  is  expensive  sea  transport  to  services  available  only  in  town.  This  is  true  especially  for 
people  on  the  west  side  of  Wairaha  River.  Hardship  is  also  described  as  extreme  difficulty  in  quickly  transporting  medical 
emergency cases to hospital. Hence, the great concern of the people is the provision of safe road transport so that everyone 
can have access to such services.   
 
Guadalcanal subproject. In terms of access, Guadalcanal can be divided into four regions: east, west, north, and south. In 
terms of nearness to the main urban center of Honiara, the north, northeast, northwest, and to some extent the eastern and 
western areas have comparatively better access to the city than the south, southeast, and southwest regions. Although the 
southern  region  is  only  a  short,  direct,  distance  from  the  northern  part  of  the  island,  the  impassable  terrain  combined  with 
inadequate  shipping  services  and  the  lack  of  roads  are  key  constraints  on  the  commercial  development  of  the  area. 
Producers  from  this  area  cannot  sell  surplus  goods  at  the  central  market  in  Honiara.  The  physical  differences  between  the 
Weather Coast and the rest of the island translate into large differences in villagers’ welfare, physical infrastructure (including 
roads),  health  and  education  services,  and  potential  for  improvement.  The  ethnic  tensions  that  affected  Solomon  Islands 
between 1999 and 2003 have had a profound impact on many people in Guadalcanal. Many people on the Weather Coast 
fled  the  fighting  and  moved  inland  or  closer  to  Honiara.  About  12,800  people  in  Guadalcanal  were  displaced  during  the 
tensions.  Security  was  restored  by  the  RAMSI  force  from  July  2003  onward,  but  the  economic,  social,  and  demographic 
impact continues in all parts of the province. As a result, Guadalcanal Province is considered to be about 10 years behind in 
terms of socioeconomic development. 
Guadalcanal  people  live  on  customary  clan  (sometimes  referred  to  as  “line”)  land.  Traditionally,  Guadalcanal  societies  are 
matrilineal:  land  and  property  are  inherited  from  the  mother  and  the  mother’s  family.  It  is  traditional  practice  for  a  male 
marrying into a line or clan to have rights to use the maternal clan land. While a male member of a clan marrying a woman 
from another clan has the right to bring his wife to live on his clan’s land, the wife and children will not have landowning rights 
on the clan land.  
Eighteen  different,  but  related,  languages  are  spoken  on  Guadalcanal.  The  languages  are  structurally  dialects  of  the  one 
prototype  Guadalcanal  language,  and  it  is  relatively  easy  for  people  from  one  language  group  to  understand  and  talk  to 
people  from  other  groups  using  their  own  dialect.  People  speaking  different  languages  or  dialects  technically  belong  to 
different clans or lines.

C. Gender and Development 

Key Issues.  
General.  There  is  a  fairly  clear  division  of  labor  between  men  and  women,  with  women  working  longer  hours  than  men  at 
routine tasks to maintain their households. Women are primarily responsible for food crops and men for cash crops (however, 
women contribute labor to activities such as copra drying and cocoa harvesting). Women interviewed said that the restoration 
of transport services on the road would reduce their burden of carrying garden produce and increase their incomes by giving 
them access to the town market. 
The major differences between women’s and men’s travel patterns are grounded in the gender-based division of labor and the 
location  in  which  this  work  is  undertaken.  The  focus  of  women’s  daily  activities  and,  therefore,  movements  is  typically  the 
homestead.  Women  tend  to  take  shorter,  more  frequent,  and  more  dispersed  trips  during  the  day  to  fetch  water,  collect 
firewood, raise livestock, and undertake cocoa and/or copra production.  
Gender  also  plays  a  role  in  determining  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  Solomon  Islands.  The  HIES  analysis  suggests  that 
households headed by women are slightly overrepresented in the lowest three expenditure deciles. In rural areas, households 
headed  by  women  are  particularly  overrepresented  in  the  lowest  quintile  (20%)  of  households,  suggesting  that  these 
households  are  among  the  poorest  in  these  areas.  After  controlling  for  household  size  and  gender  of  household  head 
(populations  of  households  headed  by  men  and  women),  a  different  picture  emerges,  with  households  headed  by  women 
earning significantly more actual income (SI$653.13 per week) and potential income (SI$1,898.92 per week) than households 
headed  by  men  (SI$136.97  per  week  [actual]  and  SI$429.28  per  week  [potential]).  The  survey  data  show  that  a  higher 
proportion  of  women  road  users  are  from  households  falling  below  the  poverty  lines  for  both  potential  and  average  actual 
weekly incomes.  
The main gender impact of the subprojects is as follows: (i) the gender-biased nature of transport in the project area and the 
differential  impact  of  failing  infrastructure  between  the  genders;  (ii)  women’s  participation  in  LBES  construction  and 
maintenance;  (iii)  the  gender  impact  of  LBES  road  construction  methods;  and  (iv)  the  role  of  women  contractors  and  the 
barriers they face in responding to the implementation of a gender-equitable LBES road maintenance program. 
Participation  in  LBES  activities  provides  an  income-generating  opportunity  presented  by  employment  in  road  maintenance. 
Participation  in  roadworks  gives  both  women  and  men  a  chance  to  have  cash.  Access  to  cash  would  give  women  an 
opportunity  to  acquire  productive  assets  and  could  contribute  to  their  economic  empowerment.  With  improved  household 
income,  there  is  likely  to  be  improved  household  welfare,  and  the  possibility  that  households  may  move  above  the  poverty 
line. Overall, the community will benefit from the increased purchasing power of the workers. With better access as a result of 
improved infrastructure, farm-gate prices may improve and commodity prices reduce.  
Any participation will need to be balanced with the usual (paid and nonpaid) workload of women and men. Women are more 
likely  to  be  disproportionately  affected  since,  in  addition  to  providing  LBES,  they  will  continue  doing  household  chores  and 
other unpaid work. This means that they will experience even more fragmented use of their time and have less time for leisure 
and rest. 
A  number  of  positive  actions  are  recommended  for  implementation  in  project  design:  (i)  identify  and  remove  any  potential 
gender  bias  within  the  local  procurement  processes;  (ii)  prequalify  contractors  including  women  or  award  extra  points 
proportionate  to  the  participation  of  women;  (iii)  provide  training  and  information  on  contracting  systems,  procedures,  and 
processes  (the  training  should  address  gender  issues  including  greater  focus  on  gender-balanced  community  participation, 
enabling an understanding of the gender impact of failing infrastructure, and of the noneconomic benefits of investment); (iv) 
provide for more flexibility in the criteria for the selection of enterprises to be trained as small and medium-sized rehabilitation 
contractors,  thus  removing  the  present  bias  toward  firms  led  by  technically  qualified  male  degree  holders  and  enabling  the 
development  of  women-owned  construction  enterprises;  (v)  identify  means  (such  as  microfinance  or  revolving  credit 
schemes) to overcome other possible barriers such as difficulty in securing the start-up capital that a small-scale contractor 
needs  to  purchase  equipment  and  tools  and  to  provide  flexibility  with  cash  flow  (especially  before  the  payment  of  the  first 
invoice); (vi) require contractors to ensure that women make up at least a third of their labor force (attaining this proportion will 
mean that the contractor must proactively invite women to sign up for construction activities rather than recruit only those who 
show interest, and also select women to be forepersons); (vii) require contractors to use task-based instead of daily rates, to 
adopt  flexible  working  times,  and  to  provide  women  with  separate  and  special  facilities  to  promote  their  participation;  (viii) 
require  contractors  not  to  allocate  women  traditional  tasks  or  to  allocate  tasks  along  existing  gender  divisions  of  labor;  (ix) 
require contractors to use alternative recruitment criteria (other than physical fitness), and not to schedule interviews on fixed 
dates, which can deter women’s participation; (x) require contractors to recruit a new workforce at regular intervals (such as 
every  5  km)  to  spread  work  opportunities  and  ensure  that  women  are  not  discouraged  by  excessive  distances  to  the 
workplace;  (xi)  require  equal  pay  for  equal  work  for  both  men  and  women;  and  (xii) require  contractors  to  submit  weekly 
records of daily labor, disaggregated by gender.
